XY_Statement: Hello, It is brought up to my attention that the strangers are arriving to Tlaxcala any day.  The Tlaxcalan people should not attack the intruders because we were informed that there was tension between the Mexica and the strangers. This tension can help the empire build a well relationship with these strangers and help us in the future. ~ Xicotencatl II
Max_Statement: Greetings, Council of Tlaxcala,  We have gathered here today to make a decision regarding these strange visitors. They seem to be hostile individuals who have been attacking other tribes with superior weapons and tactics. Although they seem to be a possible enemy, I feel that there is a possibility to to use them to our advantage. We shall keep a close eye on them and not give them our full trust but we could benefit  greatly from the advanced weapons to attack the Aztecs. Who are a much greater threat at the moment.  I propose we ally with them during this time of need. -Maxixcatl

passageHistory.The Library:
It's eight weeks into the semester and you're already drowning in work. You have your first exams this week, you need to get started on some research, and now your history professor has sprung a surprise assignment on you at the last minute—and it's due tomorrow! The only way you're going to get everything done is to pull an all-nighter. There's no way you'll be able to stay awake at home; your bed is there and it's just too tempting. So you head to the library.

It's 7 pm and the library is more crowded than usual. It looks like you're not the only one with a mountain of work to do this week! There's no way you'll be able to focus in the midst of so many people. Maybe the top floor is quieter. You head upstairs towards the study carrels, but they're all taken. It's dead quiet up here, but there's nowhere to work. You begin wandering down unfamiliar hallways, poking your head into all the different rooms, but none of them work. You're beginning to get frustrated when you notice a door you've never seen before. It's tucked into an alcove in the very back corner of the building. You decide to check this one last spot before you give up and join the masses downstairs.

The door sticks as you try to open it, but you can tell it's not locked. You give it a pull and it creaks open, revealing a tiny room piled high with books and a single, overstuffed chair. There's not a soul to be found. When you close the door behind you, you can't even hear the sound of the H-VAC that hums through the rest of the building. This is perfect. You can't believe your luck!

You unload your books and make yourself comfortable—maybe a little too comfortable. You get to work on your assignment, but within a matter of minutes your eyes get heavy. You struggle to stay awake but it's impossible to focus. Maybe a ten-minute nap will help. You tell yourself that if you just get it out of your system, you'll be good to go for the rest of the night. You close your eyes and quickly slip into a deep sleep.

Suddenly, you're startled by a loud noise!

passageHistory.Control: Votes:
STATUS OF VOTES AND HOLDS
Act 1
Start: This holds players after the Character Page at the beginning of the game. Players cannot continue until at least 12 have set their Character Statistics and joined the game.
Number of Votes Cast: 24 out of 12 votes.
Has the hold been cleared? Yes
Players who have already cast a vote:
Error: <<script>>: bad evaluation: Can't find variable: showCounterRoles
<<script>>$(output).append(showCounterRoles("Start_ctr"));<</script>>

Cuba Voted: This holds players until all three of Cortes' men have decided why they are continuing on from Cuba and into the unknown.
Number of Votes Cast: [undefined] out of 3 votes.
Has the hold been cleared? No
Players who have already cast a vote: Nobody has voted yet.
Letter Sent: This holds Aguilar until the Spaniards have arrived at Yucatan and Cortes has sent his letter to Aguilar.
Letter is currently set to: 0
Has the hold been cleared? No
Letter Received: This holds Spaniards until Aguilar has recieved the letter sent by Cortes.
Letter received is currently set to: 0.
Has the hold been cleared? No
Spaniards Meet Malinche: This holds Spaniards until Malinche has submitted her introduction link.
Malinche's story is currently set to: 0.
Has the hold been cleared? No
Tlaxcalans at the Time of the Omens: This holds Aztecs and Tlaxcalans until Tlaxcalans decide how to play the remainder of Act 1, allying with the Aztecs, spying on the Spaniards, or having a long nap.
Tlaxcalan Omens is currently set to: Spies.
Has the hold been cleared? Yes
Aztecs meet the Spaniards: This holds players until the Aztecs decide how to approach the Spaniards on the beach, with gifts, emptyhanded, or aggressively.
Gifts is currently set to: Yes.
Has the hold been cleared? Yes
The Mutiny: Tallies the number of votes that have been cast and whether for or against the Mutiny. Players are held until all 5 Spaniards have voted on whether or not to mutiny.
Mutiny Status: [undefined]. If the total is greater than 3, there is a mutiny and a new leader. If the total is less than -6, the leader of the mutiny chickened out. Otherwise, gameplay continues with the current leader in place. Number of Votes Cast: 2 out of 5 votes.
Has the hold been cleared? No
Players who have already cast a vote: Nobody has voted yet.
Tlaxcalans Attack in Veracruz: If the Tlaxcalans decide to spy on the Aztecs and the Spaniards, this holds everybody until Tlaxcalans decide whether to attack the Spaniards, the Aztecs, or nobody.
Tlaxcalans Attack is currently set to: No.
Has the hold been cleared? Yes

userId
passageHistory.return to the library_no door:
You made it through a full day of classes, but it was torture. You couldn't concentrate on anything because all you could think about was that mysterious room and the history assignment you don't remember writing. I mean, you must have written it, right? You feel a little guilty about handing it in, but you decide not to think too hard about that.

It's now late afternoon and you're finally free for the day. You hurry back to the library, excited to revisit the mystery room and its big comfy chair. You hope that if you look closely, you'll find some clue to what happened...some indication that you really did write that killer paper.

You arrive on the top floor and round the corner but you can't find the door! You swear this is exactly where you found it before, but it's not here. Confused, you scour every corner of the library to no avail. The door is nowhere to be found. You head home feeling deeply unsettled.
passageHistory.2 Return to the Library:
A week has passed and every day you've gone back to the library after class, looking for the mysterious room. You've explored every inch of the building, growing increasingly desperate with every day that goes by. Every night you've lain awake for hours, trying to figure out what happened and whether you just imagined the whole thing. You wonder if you're losing your mind, because it sure feels like it.

Your history teacher didn't help the situation when she handed back your assignment today. It turns out you really did write it. And you got an A. You now have another assignment due next week and you're extra stressed because now the bar is way too high! Your teacher is going to expect A-level work from you every time and you're just not sure it's in you.

It's the end of the day and you know you should go home and get to work on this new assignment, but you just can't stop yourself from going back to the library. It's become an obsession. Just like every other day for the last week, you start on the top floor in the back corner. You brace yourself for the worst, knowing that you won't find what you were looking for, but there it is! You can barely believe your eyes.

You carefully reach for the door knob, afraid that it will disappear before you can grasp it. But it doesn't! You turn the handle, give the door a good pull, and it opens to reveal the room exactly as you remember it: books piled high, overstuffed chair, one small table. How is this even happening? This can't be real...can it?

You make your way to the chair and you hear the door swing shut behind you. You sink down into the cushions and close your eyes, confused and relieved all at the same time. Without meaning to, you quickly drift off to sleep.
passageHistory.Tlaxcalans wait: << You wait anxiously for news from the coast. Any news at all.
passageHistory.Cortes Waits: You suffer through the journey in the hold of the boat, wondering what awaits you back on the island.
